adjectives.description: broke (not generally comparable, comparative broker or more broke, superlative brokest or most broke)

examples: It seems some of his Creditors have taken notice of it, and he was like to be broke yesterday in his absence.
If it ain't broke, don't fix it.
He was broke and rendered unfit to serve His Majesty at sea.

entries.meaning: (archaic, nonstandard or poetic) past participle of break
examples: The horse was the grey stallion he aye rode, the very beast he had ridden for many a wager with the wild lads of the Cross Keys. No man but himself durst back it, and it had lamed many a hostler lad and broke two necks in its day.

description: From Middle English broce, from Old English gebroc (“fragment”), from brecan (“to break”). Compare broken, past participle of break. Compare also Scots brock (“a scrap of meat or bread”).

entries.meaning: (papermaking) Paper or board that is discarded and repulped during the manufacturing process.
examples: Presumably, most of the brokes and waste were used up in this manner, and during the manufacture of the coarse stuff little or no attention was paid to either cleanliness or colour.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A fragment, remains, a piece broken off.

verbs.description: broke (third-person singular simple present brokes, present participle broking, simple past and past participle broked)

entries.meaning: To act as a broker; to transact business for another; synonym of broker.
examples: agents broking with various other carriers can offer additional options

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To act as procurer in love matters; to pimp.
examples: And brokes with all that can in such a suit / Corrupt the tender honour of a maid.

adjectives.description: broke (comparative more broke, superlative most broke)
